title: Refraction - beam claims for prisms X and Y

content.question:
A prism in the shape of a right triangle is made from a transparent material with an index of refraction <math alttext="n sub o" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></msub></math>, as shown in the figure. A beam of light is normally incident on the left side of the prism, passes through the prism, and is finally refracted as it emerges from the right side of the prism back into the air.
The scenario is repeated with two other prisms, both identical in shape to the original prism but made from materials with different indexes of refraction. Prism <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is made from a material with an index of refraction <math alttext="n sub X is less than n sub O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and Prism <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> is made from a material with an index of refraction <math alttext="n sub Y is greater than n sub O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub></math>. Which of the following claims about the beam of light is true?

choices.label: The beam follows the same path for prisms <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> that is does for the original prism.

The beam emerges from Prism <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, n sub X is less than n sub O, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub><mo>)</mo></mstyle></math> at an angle farther from the normal than it does from Prism <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, n sub Y is greater than n sub O, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub><mo>)</mo></mstyle></math>.

The beamâ€™s light travels faster after emerging from Prism <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, n sub X is less than n sub O, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub><mo>)</mo></mstyle></math> than it does after emerging from Prism <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, n sub Y is greater than n sub O, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub><mo>)</mo></mstyle></math>.

The beam cannot undergo total internal reflection in Prism <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> , but it might undergo total internal reflection in Prism <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, n sub Y is greater than n sub O, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub><mo>)</mo></mstyle></math> if <math alttext="n sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> is sufficiently large.

content.answer: The beam cannot undergo total internal reflection in Prism <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> , but it might undergo total internal reflection in Prism <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, n sub Y is greater than n sub O, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub><mo>)</mo></mstyle></math> if <math alttext="n sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> is sufficiently large.
